importantArticles.headline: Big Chinese technology companies gained on Thursday as investors focused on the evidence that President Donald Trump is willing to negotiate tariffs.  Alibaba rose 1.2% in Hong Kong, Tencent gained 0.8% and Baidu climbed 2.4%.  Despite Trump raising the effective tariff on Chinese goods to 125%, traders seemed optimistic a deal might eventually be reached between the world’s two largest economies—despite the risks of further escalation.

Retail traders — who kept buying shares even when benchmark indexes tumbled and institutional investors fled — notched a 17% gain on Wednesday. importantArticles.headline: Chinese stocks fell Monday as the  index slid into correction territory amid heightened market uncertainty prompted by the Trump administration’s tariff policy.  The Hang Seng Tech index tracks some of mainland China’s largest technology firms listed in Hong Kong such as search engine provider Baidu, e-commerce giants Alibaba and JD.com, and game developer  Tencent  The index closed down 2% Monday and has thereby dropped 11% since its recent peak on March 18.  Baidu  stock dropped 2.4% ahead of the open.

importantArticles.headline: HONG KONG (Reuters) -Alibaba Group Chairman Joe Tsai said on Tuesday the tech giant would recommence hiring, emboldened with more confidence following President Xi Jinping's February meeting with business entrepreneurs.  He also expressed concern about some very big investment announcements in artificial intelligence in the U.S., saying it could be the start of a bubble.  Tsai lauded the rare meeting between Xi and big names in Chinese tech, including Alibaba co-founder Jack Ma, which marked a distinct thawing in Beijing's approach to the sector.
importantArticles.title: Alibaba says to restart hiring, sees signs of start of AI bubble in the US
